================================= Entity Chunks for D-LINK_PAUSE.REQUEST =================================
Entity: D-LINK_PAUSE.REQUEST
Description: The D-LINK_PAUSE.request is sent by HLE to enter a power-saving mode A message requesting lower layers to enter a power-saving mode while keeping the state to 'Matched' The D-LINK_PAUSE.request requests lower layers to enter a power saving mode. While being in this mode, the state will be kept to 'Matched'.
With receiving a D-LINK_PAUSE.request, the EVSE shall switch to control pilot state X1 and may switch the low-layer communication module into low-power mode. The logical network parameter set shall be stored for continuing the data link after the sleeping phase.
With receiving a D-LINK_PAUSE.request, the EV shall change to control pilot state Bx. Unpowering the low-layer communication module is optional. The logical network parameter set shall be stored for continuing the data link after the sleeping phase.
This entity is not mentioned in the provided candidate answers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Entity: HLE
Description: A higher layer entity involved in the binding process With receiving a D-LINK_TERMINATE.request from HLE, the communication node shall leave the logical network within TP_match_leave. All parameters related to the current link shall be set to the default value and shall change to the status 'Unmatched'.

What is Logical Network?:
================================= Entity Chunks for LOGICAL NETWORK =================================
Entity: LOGICAL NETWORK
Description: Logical Network consists of low-layer communication stations using the same network key." "The Test System ensures the SUT leaves the logical network using the CM_NW_STATS message sequence. A logical network is a set of low-layer communication stations using the same network key, allowing only members to exchange encrypted data." "The logical network refers to a structured network configuration that is used during the testing process. A logical network is defined for layer 2.
Only members of the same logical network are able to exchange encrypted payload data and are visible for each other on higher layers. Different logical networks might exist on the same physical media at the same time and are typically used for network segmentation.
The NID of the logical network shall be derived from the NMK according to [HPGP], 4.4.3.1 using a security level value of 0b00.
According to the low-layer communication technology, a logical network might have to be built in order to enhance the communication.
In order to create the logical network, both EV and EVSE shall use the CM_SLAC_ MATCH MMEs defined in the [HPGP] messages, using sequences defined in Figure A.1.
The logical network may need several seconds to discover that the EV has left the network. When the low-layer communication module leaves the logical network, it shall inform HLE through the D-LINK_READY.indication (no link). At any time an EVSE switches to a private logical network, the local NMK shall be set per random value to ensure a unique logical network.
The configuration of the low-layer communication module with the parameters of the logical network may be done with the MMEs CM_SET_KEY.REQ and CM_SET_KEY.CNF. After the EV has finished the matching decision, it requests the parameter for the logical network from the selected EVSE by means of the message CM_SLAC_MATCH.REQ. The selected EVSE responses to the EV request with a CM_SLAC_MATCH.CNF, which contains all parameters to be set to join the logical network of the EVSE.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Entity: LOW-LAYER COMMUNICATION
Description: Low-layer communication consists of functions managed by OSI layer 1 and layer 2 of the modem. According to the low-layer communication technology, a logical network might have to be built in order to enhance the communication.
With receiving a D-LINK_TERMINATE.request from HLE, the low-layer communication module shall leave the logical network, reset the NMK, and switch to matching state 'Unmatched'. The low-layer communication module shall follow the Clause 'Leaving an AVLN' defined in the [HPGP].
The low-layer communication module shall join the logical network only if the EV_ Discovering_status is EVSE_FOUND. The configuration of the low-layer communication module with the parameters of the logical network may be done with the MMEs CM_SET_KEY.REQ and CM_SET_KEY.CNF.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Entity: TEST SYSTEM
Description: The "Test System" is an automated system designed to execute various test procedures and validate the compliance and functionality of a System Under Test (SUT). Primarily, it performs these test procedures according to ISO standards, including ISO 15118-3:2015 and ISO 15118-5:2018, which are related to the communication protocols for electric vehicle charging infrastructure.

The Test System executes a wide range of procedures such as transitions, connection loss checks, establishing new logical networks, and specific behaviors like message validation and attenuation characterization. It also sends and receives messages, including protocols like CM_SLAC_MATCH.REQ and CM_SLAC_MATCH.CNF, to ensure proper communication between electric vehicles and charging systems during testing phases.

This system operates within a predefined testing environment, handling the procedural setup required for validating V2G (Vehicle-to-Grid) communication sessions. It conducts various checks, controls test scenarios, measures attenuation values, and verifies that the SUT meets the required performance and regulatory standards. Ultimately, the Test System ensures that the procedures described in the relevant documents are executed effectively, maintaining compliance with specified protocols and standards. Entity: EV
Description: EV (Electric Vehicle) is referred to in the context of testing processes, such as the SLAC matching and attenuation characterization." EV (Electric Vehicle) refers to a vehicle powered by electric motors that uses energy from rechargeable batteries. It interacts with the EVSE (Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment) for tasks such as charging, energy management, signal strength measurement, and communication. The EV is responsible for following validation steps and processes outlined in standards such as ISO 15118-3. It receives HomePlug Green PHY signals from the EVSE to facilitate communication and can detect loss of communication, switching to basic charging mode or stopping charging depending on the EVSE's settings. Additionally, the EV participates in processes like the AMP MAP Exchange and is a central component in the matching and communication processes defined in the document. Overall, EVs are key participants in the network management context, ensuring proper interaction and compliance with the designated standards. The charging process uses bidirectional signalling indicating EV related information through control pilot states.
9 Matching EV — EVSE process

In case basic charging is used as back-up of HLC-C (e.g. when HLC-C has failed), the duty cycle is allowed to change due to dynamically changed grid information, according [IEC-1] requirements.
The duty cycle of the control pilot signal indicates EVSE related information during the charging process.

Entity: ISO 15118-5:2018(E)
Description: ISO 15118-5:2018(E) is a comprehensive international standard published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in 2018. This standard document is an integral part of the ISO 15118 series, specifically focusing on electric vehicle (EV) communication protocols and conductive charging systems. It outlines specific requirements for communication interfaces between electric vehicles and the power grid, ensuring compatibility and interoperability.

The document provides detailed technical standards and procedures for validating and testing electric vehicle communication systems, including protocols for Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) communication and Physical Layer Conformance (PLC) test cases. It includes conformance test cases for both Electric Vehicle Communication Controllers (EVCC) and Supply Equipment Communication Controllers (SECC), covering the physical and data link layers of the communication interface.

ISO 15118-5:2018(E) addresses the specifications for processing various test cases, ensuring adherence to standardized communication protocols and verification procedures to guarantee reliable and secure interactions between electric vehicles and their charging infrastructure. The document emphasizes guidelines and standards related to the behavior, validation, and conformance of communication systems within the electric vehicle supply equipment (EVSE) and electric vehicles.

Referenced throughout the text, ISO 15118-5:2018(E) is central to the validation processes outlined in the document and provides a reserved set of rights, expectations, and supplementary guidelines. By detailing the necessary conformance requirements and technical parameters, it serves as a crucial standard for the development and operational testing of electric vehicle charging systems. Entity: CM_ATTEN_CHAR.IND
Description: The Test System sends the CM_ATTEN_CHAR.IND message The CM_ATTEN_CHAR.IND message is sent after the TT_EV_atten_results timer expires An indication message containing attenuation entries and other parameters The received attenuation values within CM_ATTEN_CHAR.IND message are based on the physical channel, and the ATTEN_PROFILE within the message CM_ATTEN_CHAR.IND shall be calculated by arithmetic mean of the ATTEN_PROFILE of the CM_ATTEN_PROFILE.IND of previous M-SOUNDS corrected by the attenuation of the receive path AttnRx-EVSE.
If the NUM_SOUNDS field in a CM_ATTEN_CHAR.IND is zero, then the ATTEN_PROFILE has no significance and the whole messages shall be ignored. It is up to the EV to decide what number of M-SOUNDS used for the attenuation profile is sufficient for its decision (i.e. whether to discard CM_ATTEN_CHAR.IND if NUM_SOUNDs is less than C_EV_match_MNBC).
If a CM_ATTEN_CHAR.IND is received and its origin is an EVSE that has not sent a CM_SLAC_PARM.CNF before, the message shall be processed and not ignored.

What is CM_AMP_MAP.REQ?:
================================= Entity Chunks for CM_AMP_MAP =================================
Entity: CM_AMP_MAP
Description: The transmission power values within the CM_AMP_MAP are related to the reference value of −50 dBm/Hz, serving as a baseline AMDATA values are used to quantify the transmission power values within the CM_AMP_MAP, with specific resolution CM_AMP_MAP refers to a set of parameters or data structures used to map transmission power values in a communication system The CM_AMP_MAP.REQ MME has the following two different functions, depending on the source/destination of the message. The amplitude map exchange is an optional function to request the counterpart low-layer communication module to reduce the transmission power for certain carriers. The requesting device sends a CM_AMP_MAP.REQ command which has to be confirmed by the counterpart node by a CM_AMP_MAP.CNF message.
If a low-layer communication module has sent a CM_AMP_MAP.REQ but does not receive a valid CM_AMP_MAP.CNF within the max(TT_match_response), it shall retransmit the CM_AMP_MAP.REQ. The timer shall be restarted with any retry. A maximum of C_EV_match_retry retransmissions shall be performed. If after these retransmissions the low-layer communication module has not received valid response within max(TT_match_response), the matching process shall be considered as FAILED.
If the requested node receives another CM_AMP_MAP.REQ, this means that the counterpart station retransmitted its request for some reason (i.e. the CM_AMP_MAP.CNF was not received); the requested node shall respond to the request again.
A.9.6 Amplitude map exchange; A.9.6.1 Functional description — CM_AMP_MAP.REQ sent from one host to another host through the low-layer communication is designated to transmit the requested transmission power per carrier to the destination host to be included in its amplitude map calculation.

This message is sent in response to the CM_AMP_MAP.REQ message, indicating the result of the request. The CM_AMP_MAP.CNF message is a confirmation message that indicates the result of the request sent by the CM_AMP_MAP.REQ command. It includes a result code where 0x00 indicates success, 0x01 indicates failure, and 0x02 to 0xFF are reserved.
If a low-layer communication module has sent a CM_AMP_MAP.REQ but does not receive a valid CM_AMP_MAP.CNF within the max(TT_match_response), it shall retransmit the CM_AMP_MAP.REQ.

With receiving a D-LINK_TERMINATE.request from HLE, the communication node shall leave the logical network within TP_match_leave. All parameters related to the current link shall be set to the default value and shall change to the status “Unmatched”.
With receiving a D-LINK_ERROR.request from HLE, the EVSE’s communication node shall stay in X2 control pilot state, leave the logical network within TP_ match_leave, and change the matching state to 'Unmatched' to be ready for a new matching process.

Entity: HPGP
Description: EVSE utilizes HPGP specifications for defining and using CM_SLAC_MATCH MMEs." "PLC and HPGP are both technologies involved in the power line communication signal measurement and testing procedures. HPGP (HomePlug Green PHY) refers to the technology standard used in the EV- EVSE matching process." "HPGP stands for HomePlug Green PHY, a specification for power line communication technology used in the calibration and testing procedures. [HPGP] implements the ISP as a coexistence mechanism. The ISP, defined by [IEEE], allows coexistence between devices that implement non-interoperable protocols. Using ISP, 1901 access, 1901 wavelet, 1901 FFT, LRWBS, and ITU-T G.hn, devices are able to coexist.
The HomePlug Green PHY signals on the control pilot line are compliant with [HPGP] except the signal coupling, signal levels, and carrier usage.
The physical layer of the HomePlug Green PHY technology is fully described in [HPGP].
The data SAP is the ETH SAP. The ETH SAP is completely covered by the [HPGP].
HomePlug Green PHY (HPGP) is referenced in the context of control pilot line and signal measurement procedures in ISO 15118-3 and ISO 15118-5.
The content is shown in Table A.9 for the CM_AMP_MAP.REQ message defined in [HPGP] to exchange an amplitude map. The highlighted entities of Figure 2 represent the whole HomePlug Green PHY MAC and PHY layer and are covered by [HPGP].

Entity: EVSE
Description: EVSE (Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment) is a crucial technology involved in the charging and validation processes for electric vehicles (EVs). It is the hardware and infrastructure responsible for delivering electrical energy to charge EVs, commonly referred to as a charging station. EVSE systems ensure effective energy transfer and compliance with standards such as ISO 15118-3:2015 and IEC 61851-1, making them essential for the interface and interaction with electric vehicles.

The document frequently references EVSE within the context of testing, validation, and charging processes. EVSE is involved in SLAC (Signal Level Attenuation Characterization) testing, which entails signal strength measurements and compliance with local regulations. It is also part of various validation processes mentioned multiple times in the document.

EVSE performs several important functions during the charging process, including managing the charging activities, handling errors, addressing communication losses, and ensuring secure energy transfer. Equipped with a communication module, often employing HomePlug Green PHY signals, EVSE facilitates communication required for the SLAC process, amplitude map (AMP) exchanges, and logical network parameter exchanges with the EVs.

Overall, EVSE is integral to the electric vehicle charging infrastructure, ensuring proper energy delivery, communication, and compliance with standard protocols, thereby supporting the broader ecosystem of electric vehicle transportation.

Entity: PTC
Description: PTC observes Protocol Specific Parameters to ensure they remain within the valid range during IEC 61851-1 testing. PTC stands for Parallel Test Component, which continuously observes the IEC 61851-1 signaling protocol parameters during the testing process." "Parallel Test Component, a testing tool used in conjunction with MTC for validating different aspects of EVCC and SECC systems. Requirements of IEC 61851-1 PTC for SECC testing: The IEC 61851‐1 PTC for SECC testing shall provide a function to change its valid frequency range.
Requirements of IEC 61851-1 PTC for SECC or EVCC testing: The IEC 61851‐1 PTC for SECC or EVCC testing shall provide a function to change its valid duty cycle range.
Requirements of EIM status PTC for SECC testing: The EIM status PTC for SECC testing shall provide a function to inform the MTC if the EIM authorization is successful. If no change event occurs within a given time [ms], the function shall report an error.
Requirements of IEC 61851-1 PTC for SECC or EVCC testing: The IEC 61851‐1 PTC for SECC or EVCC testing shall provide a function to confirm a change from/to a given PWM state. This function shall wait for receiving a state change event from IEC 61851‐1 SUT adapter. If no change event occurs within a given time [ms], the function shall return an error.
Requirements of IEC 61851-1 PTC for SECC or EVCC testing: The IEC 61851‐1 PTC for SECC or EVCC testing shall provide a function to change its valid PWM state condition. This function shall change the internal monitoring condition to a given PWM state, which the IEC 61851‐1 PTC will consider as the next valid PWM state.
The parallel test component (PTC) for IEC 61851‐1 signaling continuously observes the protocol specific parameters positive voltage (state), frequency, duty cycle and the proximity resistor value in accordance with the defined valid range of values (as defined in IEC 61851‐1:2017, Annex A), during the entire test case execution.

Entity: ISO 15118-5:2018(E)
Description: ISO 15118-5:2018(E) is a comprehensive international standard published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in 2018. This standard document is an integral part of the ISO 15118 series, specifically focusing on electric vehicle (EV) communication protocols and conductive charging systems. It outlines specific requirements for communication interfaces between electric vehicles and the power grid, ensuring compatibility and interoperability.

The document provides detailed technical standards and procedures for validating and testing electric vehicle communication systems, including protocols for Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) communication and Physical Layer Conformance (PLC) test cases. It includes conformance test cases for both Electric Vehicle Communication Controllers (EVCC) and Supply Equipment Communication Controllers (SECC), covering the physical and data link layers of the communication interface.

ISO 15118-5:2018(E) addresses the specifications for processing various test cases, ensuring adherence to standardized communication protocols and verification procedures to guarantee reliable and secure interactions between electric vehicles and their charging infrastructure. The document emphasizes guidelines and standards related to the behavior, validation, and conformance of communication systems within the electric vehicle supply equipment (EVSE) and electric vehicles.

Referenced throughout the text, ISO 15118-5:2018(E) is central to the validation processes outlined in the document and provides a reserved set of rights, expectations, and supplementary guidelines. By detailing the necessary conformance requirements and technical parameters, it serves as a crucial standard for the development and operational testing of electric vehicle charging systems. International Standard ISO 15118-5 First edition 2018-02, Road vehicles — Vehicle to grid communication interface — Part 5: Physical layer and data link layer conformance test.
INTERNATIONAL STANDARD ISO 15118-5 First edition 2018-02.

Entity: SECC
Description: SECC refers to the Supply Equipment Communication Controller, a critical component involved in electric vehicle (EV) charging systems. It plays a significant role in the communication and control protocols required for efficient and standardized EV charging processes. Within the scope of ISO 15118-5:2018 and IEC 61851-1 standards, SECC is extensively mentioned as being integral to various test cases, scenarios, and validation procedures.

SECC is responsible for handling communication within the charging infrastructure, managing SLAC message sequences, and overseeing the signaling of duty cycles during testing. It is often the system under test (SUT) in diverse configurations, tasked with ensuring compliance with established standards. Additionally, SECC is involved in both the characterization and attenuation of test cases, contributing to the broader objectives of the Smart Electric Vehicle (EV) Charging ecosystem.

In some contexts, SECC is also referred to as the Smart Electric Charging Configuration and the Smart Electric Charging Consortium, highlighting its organizational role in standardizing EV charging protocols. Overall, SECC is a fundamental entity that supports the implementation, validation, and monitoring of EV communication and control protocols to ensure seamless operation across different charging systems. The IEC 61851‐1 PTC for SECC testing shall provide a function to change its valid frequency range and its valid duty cycle range.

Moreover, HAL_61851_Listener facilitates listening for specific test signals and handling communications during test cases, ensuring proper configurations and behaviors are met. The component's functionalities are integral to the testing framework, managing the duty cycle in communication protocols and validating configurations within the SECC and EVCC systems. Entity: EVCC_TESTER
Description: EVCC_Tester is an entity, system, or technology component involved in the testing and validation of Electric Vehicle Communication Controllers (EVCC). It is primarily responsible for running various test cases within the context of the ISO 15118-5:2018 standard, ensuring conformance with electric vehicle communication protocols. The EVCC_Tester executes specific functions and procedures described in the document, such as initiating EVCC configuration, managing the IEC 61851 listener, and handling SLAC (Signal Level Attenuation Characterization) matching. Additionally, it verifies functions like CmSetKey and PLCLinkStatus to ensure correct behavior.

The EVCC_Tester's tasks include testing configurations and behaviors, running attenuation characterization tests, and ensuring proper communication protocols between electric vehicles and charging systems (EVSE). It acts as the main test component when the System Under Test (SUT) is an EVCC, conducting validation procedures and evaluating the PLC link status. The EVCC_Tester plays a crucial role in the overall verification process, ensuring the reliability and efficiency of electric vehicle charging communication systems. The MTC shall be able to detect and control link status information by using special functions depending on the MTC's type (EVCC_Tester / SECC_Tester).

Entity: SECC_TESTER
Description: SECC_Tester is an entity, system, or tool involved in the testing and validation process described in the document. Specifically, the SECC_Tester operates within the context of the Supply Equipment Communication Controller (SECC) environment, executing test cases and procedures to ensure compliance with electric vehicle communication protocols, such as SLAC (Signal-Level Attenuation Characterization) and the ISO/IEC 15118 standards.

The SECC_Tester performs functions such as the CM_AMP_MAP exchange, receives CM_AMP_MAP messages, and is responsible for validating configurations and communication protocols like the IEC 61851 listener and SLAC testers. It serves as a crucial component in validating the procedures defined in the SECC environment, ensuring that the tested systems meet the necessary standards for communication protocols.

Moreover, SECC_Tester is mentioned alongside EVCC_Tester, indicating its collaborative role in the overall testing framework. It runs various specific test cases, including TC_SECC_CMN_VTB_CmSlacMatch_016, TC_SECC_CMN_VTB_CmSlacMatch_017, and TC_SECC_CMN_VTB_CmSlacMatch_018, to determine the performance and compliance of the system under test. The SECC_Tester's activities are critical for ensuring the accuracy and reliability of the protocol implementations in electric vehicle communication systems.

In essence, the SECC_Tester is a comprehensive testing platform or environment used to execute, validate, and verify the compliance of communication protocols and performance standards within the scope of electric vehicle charging communication systems, contributing significantly to the quality assurance processes detailed in the document. The MTC shall be able to detect and control link status information by using special functions depending on the MTC's type (EVCC_Tester / SECC_Tester).

Entity: SLAC
Description: SLAC, which stands for Signal Level Attenuation Characterization, is a critical protocol and process involved in the communication and validation procedures for electric vehicle (EV) charging and Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) systems. SLAC is primarily mentioned in the context of ISO 15118-5:2018(E) and is used to characterize and assess signal attenuation in electric vehicle communication systems, ensuring proper connections and reliable communications between electric vehicles (EVs) and electric vehicle supply equipment (EVSE). 

SLAC involves various test cases, configurations, and procedures to validate communication modules and manage communication exchanges in electric vehicle charging systems. It is an integral part of the test conditions and configurations related to attenuation characterization, power line communication, matching requests, and the readiness of communication modules within EVCC (Electric Vehicle Communication Controller) systems. Additionally, SLAC refers to specific protocol and data structures defined for the physical and data link layers, playing a vital role in the standardization and validation processes for electric vehicle communication and charging infrastructure.

In summary, SLAC (Signal Level Attenuation Characterization) is a key technology and protocol used in assessing communication signal levels, managing protocol exchanges, and ensuring the effectiveness and reliability of electric vehicle charging and communication systems, as detailed in various test cases and standards.

Entity: ISO 15118-3
Description: ISO 15118-3 is a part of the ISO 15118 series, which specifies standards for vehicle-to-grid communication interfaces, ensuring interoperability between different manufacturers. Published in 2015, ISO 15118-3 focuses on the physical and data link layer requirements essential for secure and efficient communication between electric vehicles (EVs) and charging stations (EVSE). This standard encompasses various aspects including the setup of logical networks, EMC requirements, performance times, timeouts, calibration of power levels, and charging profiles pertinent to EVCC (Electric Vehicle Communication Controller) and SECC (Supply Equipment Communication Controller) systems.

ISO 15118-3 defines the procedures and protocols needed for these layers to support high-level communication across the EVSE and EVs, facilitating a standardized approach to conductive charging systems for electric vehicles. This part of the ISO 15118 standard also ensures that the communication interface between EVs and charging stations (V2G) is reliable, covering message exchanges and other relevant communication protocols. Road vehicles — Vehicle to grid communication interface — Part 3: Physical and data link layer requirements.

Entity: ISO 15118-5:2018
Description: ISO 15118-5:2018 is a standard published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in 2018. As part of the ISO 15118 series, this standard is crucial for communication interfaces related to electric vehicle (EV) charging. Specifically, ISO 15118-5:2018 focuses on the procedures and requirements for vehicle-to-grid (V2G) communication sessions, including conformance testing for communication protocols.

The standard outlines various protocols and test-case specifications necessary for testing and validating the communication between electric vehicles and charging infrastructure. It addresses communication protocols related to the conductive charging of EVs, detailing requirements for specific technical configurations, message protocols such as the CM_AMP_MAP.REQ message, and test procedures for these systems.

ISO 15118-5:2018 is repeatedly referenced in technical documents and guides the development and implementation of communication protocols to ensure interoperability and effectiveness in EV charging systems. The standard includes comprehensive guidelines and specifications for conformance tests at both the physical and data link layers, ensuring compatibility and reliability in the communication between EVs and supply equipment. Entity: ISO 15118-5:2018(E)
Description: ISO 15118-5:2018(E) is a comprehensive international standard published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in 2018. This standard document is an integral part of the ISO 15118 series, specifically focusing on electric vehicle (EV) communication protocols and conductive charging systems. It outlines specific requirements for communication interfaces between electric vehicles and the power grid, ensuring compatibility and interoperability.

The document provides detailed technical standards and procedures for validating and testing electric vehicle communication systems, including protocols for Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) communication and Physical Layer Conformance (PLC) test cases. It includes conformance test cases for both Electric Vehicle Communication Controllers (EVCC) and Supply Equipment Communication Controllers (SECC), covering the physical and data link layers of the communication interface.

ISO 15118-5:2018(E) addresses the specifications for processing various test cases, ensuring adherence to standardized communication protocols and verification procedures to guarantee reliable and secure interactions between electric vehicles and their charging infrastructure. The document emphasizes guidelines and standards related to the behavior, validation, and conformance of communication systems within the electric vehicle supply equipment (EVSE) and electric vehicles.

Referenced throughout the text, ISO 15118-5:2018(E) is central to the validation processes outlined in the document and provides a reserved set of rights, expectations, and supplementary guidelines. By detailing the necessary conformance requirements and technical parameters, it serves as a crucial standard for the development and operational testing of electric vehicle charging systems.
